articles.headline: Why Companies Like Toys ‘R’ Us Love to Go Bust in Richmond, Va.
articles.snippet: The federal bankruptcy court in Virginia’s capital moves quickly, has expert judges and legal precedents that are favorable to companies, and a reputation for approving huge fees for lawyers.
articles.abstract: The federal bankruptcy court in Virginia’s capital moves quickly, has expert judges and legal precedents that are favorable to companies, and a reputation for approving huge fees for lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Toys “R” Us world headquarters are on a sprawling wooded campus next to a reservoir in Wayne, N.J., on a street that bears the name of the company’s iconic mascot, Geoffrey the giraffe.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Senate Plans to End Obamacare Mandate in Revised Tax Proposal
articles.snippet: Republicans also said they would set all of their tax cuts for individuals to expire at the end of 2025, but deep cuts in the corporate tax rate would be permanent.
articles.abstract: Republicans also said they would set all of their tax cuts for individuals to expire at the end of 2025, but deep cuts in the corporate tax rate would be permanent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans have decided to include the repeal of the Affordable Care Act’s requirement that most people have health insurance into the sprawling tax rewrite, merging the fight over health care with the high-stakes effort to cut taxes.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: An Alabama Senate Candidate Keeps Democratic Leaders Away — but Not Their Money
articles.snippet: Doug Jones has portrayed his race for the Senate as an Alabama effort, apart from the national Democratic Party, but he is reaping the fruit of an energized party.
articles.abstract: Doug Jones has portrayed his race for the Senate as an Alabama effort, apart from the national Democratic Party, but he is reaping the fruit of an energized party.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, Doug Jones, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Alabama, appears to be running a lonely race against Roy S. Moore, the arch-conservative former judge whose candidacy is being swallowed by accusations that he sexually assaulted teenage girls.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Jeff Sessions Denies Lying to Congress on Contacts With Russia
articles.snippet: Before the House Judiciary Committee, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he could not recall a campaign adviser’s briefing on Russia but did remember stopping a Trump-Putin meeting.
articles.abstract: Before the House Judiciary Committee, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he could not recall a campaign adviser’s briefing on Russia but did remember stopping a Trump-Putin meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Tuesday denied, again, lying to Congress about the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia. He said he had forgotten about a campaign round-table in which an aide played up his Russian connections and suggested arranging a meeting for Donald J. Trump in Moscow.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: ‘I Am Alive’: Survivors of Iran Earthquake Mourn as Government Scrambles to Help
articles.snippet: A New York Times correspondent visited villages in western Iran near the epicenter of Sunday night’s earthquake.
articles.abstract: A New York Times correspondent visited villages in western Iran near the epicenter of Sunday night’s earthquake.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUIK-E HASAN, Iran — In Kuik-e Hasan, a village of 800 people in the foothills of the Zagros mountains, Moadel Yari, 35, stood biting his lip as he recited the names of his lost relatives: “Amin, Hajar, Toba, Hajin, Abdellah, Boshra, Ozve, Somron.”

articles.headline: Zimbabwe’s Military, in Apparent Takeover, Says It Has Custody of Mugabe
articles.snippet: President Robert G. Mugabe was in custody, military officials said, adding that they would be “targeting criminals around him” as “the situation in our country has moved to another level.”
articles.abstract: President Robert G. Mugabe was in custody, military officials said, adding that they would be “targeting criminals around him” as “the situation in our country has moved to another level.”
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Zimbabwe’s military said early Wednesday that it had taken custody of President Robert Mugabe, the world’s oldest head of state and one of Africa’s longest-serving leaders, in what increasingly appeared to be a military takeover in the southern African nation.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Moyo and Norimitsu Onishi

articles.headline: Snapchat’s New Test: Grow Like Facebook, Without the Baggage
articles.snippet: Under pressure from investors, Snap is making radical changes. Can it emulate Facebook without losing its innovative spirit?
articles.abstract: Under pressure from investors, Snap is making radical changes. Can it emulate Facebook without losing its innovative spirit?
articles.lead_paragraph: In today’s social media industry, you essentially have two options: Die young, or live long enough to turn into Facebook.
